awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  A mental health screening tool for youth using AI and game-based technology
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is improve pediatric mental health outcomes.   An estimated twenty percent of children suffer with a diagnosable mental health condition and half of those will show signs and symptoms before the age of 14. Suicide is the second leading cause of death among children aged 10+; affected children that do not receive intervention or appropriate services grow into adults with adverse outcomes.   The proposed project develops a modern mental health screener to equip clinicians and educate families by tracking  mental health vital signs similar to height, weight, hearing, vision and other signs of health. 

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project will advance a new mental health screening tool. In a gamified, web-based platform, children aged 4-18 will engage in a dynamic question set designed to identify risk factors known as indicators of mental health concerns. Using a novel combination of artificial intelligence for voice and facial biomarkers, sentiment analysis and machine learning, the screener will provide a first-of-its-kind mental health baseline used by doctors and families to better understand the child’s unique mental health.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
After millions of dollars in "awareness" campaigns, the CDC reports that 20% of children suffer with a diagnosable mental health condition and half of those will show signs and symptoms before the age of 14. Suicide is the second leading cause of death among children aged 10+. Further, the CDC reports the average delay between onset of symptoms and diagnosis is currently 11 years; for a 6-year old with symptoms, it will likely take until age 17 to be properly treated. Children who do not receive intervention or treatment are becoming generations of adults with adverse outcomes. 

Unfortunately, the screening tools that could help have not advanced since the 1990s when the Patient Health Questionnaire (PHQ) was first introduced. According to the American Academy of Pediatrics, mental health screening rarely begins before the age of 12 unless a child loses functioning, thereby making early intervention impossible.

Decades of research support early intervention as the best path to long-term health which is only possible if we assess before symptoms emerge, as we do for every other health condition. 

In partnership with The National Science Foundation (NSF), fT has introduced a 21st Century solution.

The tScreen is a 21st-century digital mental health screener that leverages AI to provide practitioners with the largest data set of mental health information on the market. tScreen is age-appropriate for non-reading children aged 5-9.  TweenScreen is a similar tool for ages 9-16. Both tools collect health data about Adverse Childhood Experiences(TM), Positive Childhood Experiences(TM), Positive findings, Relationships, routines, functioning in school, home, and with peers, Family disruptions, Anxiety, Depression, and suicidality.

Using a combination of artificial intelligence, sentiment analysis and machine learning, these screeners provide first-of-its-kind mental health baselines that are being used with doctors and families to better understand the child's unique mental health qualities. 

In a study conducted in Fall of 2023 for NSF Phase I work, 100 children ages 5-16, were asked to take the fT screeners as well as the Pediatric Symptom Checklist (PSC). The goal was to compare the fT methods with the current PSC and discern validity, as well as get feedback from parents and children. 

An 87% match was achieved in comparative data; of the 15 respondents identified as "impaired" on the PSC, 87% (13) were identified by one or more of the flags on the tScreen or TweenScreen. Further, the tScreen and TweenScreen added considerably more data to the report by identifying specific areas of concern and the respondent's own thoughts to related questions. Context was often validated with the addition of anecdotal parent reporting and sibling comparisons. As expected, the results showed that kids are capable of expressing various mental health concerns. The benefit of the tScreen and TweenScreen is that the automated results can analyze a multitude of data sets, including whether they showed signs of anxiety, depression, or suicidality, along with the associated risk factors from their overall environment or personal feelings. In the pilot sample, 62 (out of 100 children) reported the death of a loved one, and their personal accounts indicated this ranged from a grandparent to a pet. The tScreen and TweenScreen afford children the opportunity to share their thoughts on these experiences, which can be related to other emotions (e.g., sadness). Of all the research study respondents, only 3.5% of the open-ended questions offered were skipped. Open-ended answers were highly relevant to the overall wellness report in that they provided context and more evidence of the root causes behind the feelings discussed during the assessment.

Interestingly, children often tried to write in answers or comments on the PSC confirming that it is not well suited for comprehensive screening.

After children had completed the video interview, the system analyzed their emotions. The system reviewed quality (e.g., mumbling), pitch, intensity, speaking rate, text pauses, and text frequency, as well as keyword frequency. The flagging of specific keyword frequencies determines if the child is expressing any behavior a clinician would be interested in. Finally, our system ran sentiment analysis to assess if the child's given answer is overall positive, negative, or neutral. 

The final report highlights correlations from the interview questions to impact on mental health and well-being.

The most significant result was confirmation of engaged kids and the ability  to collect the largest data set of information to help address mental health concerns early. Repeatedly kids claimed that tScreen and TweenScreen "was so fun" and that they "wanted to take them again." 

In partnership with The NSF, fT has created the first substantial update to pediatric mental health screening tools in 30 years. Further research will focus on identifying baselines, key correlations in risk and protective factors to anxiety and depression. Once fully developed tScreen and TweenScreen will change the trajectory of mental health concerns for generations to come.

 


Last Modified: 10/27/2023
Modified by: Wendy B Ward
